justification: The article states that "participants also completed… a canonical prosocial choice task; either the Dictator Game (DG)" and later describes donations in the DG as the behavioral index of prosocial giving.

It notes that participants sometimes played "the Prisoner's Dilemma (PD)" in which they made a simultaneous choice whether to cooperate, treating the amount of cooperation as a measure of prosocial behavior.

The authors explain that Capraro and Rand (2018) "used a 'Trade-Off Game' (TOG) to empirically dissociate the hypothesized morality preference"—participants’ selections under moral framing reveal the strength of this construct.
Within the TOG one option "minimized inequity – all participants earned the same amount"; choosing this equitable option is used to diagnose a preference for equity.
In the same TOG, the alternative choice "maximized efficiency – … the group earned more"; selecting this efficient option operationalizes a preference for efficiency.
